awd_titl_txt: Identifying Stakeholder Perceptions and Practices to Develop a Comprehensive Framework for Bioscience Industry Internships for Underrepresented Youth
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) Program. Bioscience fields are changing to keep pace with rapid advances in technologies and scientific innovations. These fields need diverse, prepared personnel who can meet workforce demands using cutting-edge technologies and a deep knowledge of science. This project meets this need by preparing underrepresented high school students for the bioscience workforce through innovative internship experiences. This project will pair eleventh- and twelfth-grade students with dedicated mentors from bioscience industries during paid summer internships. Students will also participate in a workforce preparation class, with an emphasis on biotechnology industries, as part of their high school coursework. The project will study the perspectives and practices of different stakeholders, including the high school biotechnology teachers, students, and industry mentors. The analysis of several types of data will result in an empirically-based, comprehensive framework that outlines the elements of impactful internships in bioscience industries. Findings will be widely disseminated to researchers and practitioners, resulting in new approaches for broadening participation in the bioscience workforce.  

Building from 25 years of providing internships for high school students in biotechnology industries, Biotech Partners will iteratively study and improve its internship intervention, resulting in an empirically-based framework that outlines the features of successful internships in bioscience industries. The project will seek to answer the following research question: In what roles and in what ways do business and industry workforce members motivate students from diverse underrepresented populations to become aware of, interested in, and prepare for biotechnology careers, and support teachers in efforts to promote biotechnology workforce awareness and interest? The internship intervention will serve over 300 high school students, 85% of whom identify as youth of color. The internship intervention includes a high school class focused on workforce preparation in biotechnology industries, after-school tutoring, and paid summer internships with biotechnology firms. Research participants include approximately 300 high school students; industry representatives from 15 bioscience industries; six program staff members who facilitate the internships; and four high school teachers. Using constant comparative analytic techniques, the research team will qualitatively analyze transcripts from interviews and focus groups with a purposefully-selected subset of each group of research participants. Using repeated measures analyses of variance, the research team will quantitatively analyze surveys given to students and mentors. This project will advance knowledge about the features of internships that foster workforce preparedness among underrepresented high school students in the biosciences. This project will result in a comprehensive framework for impactful internships that will be widely disseminated to relevant stakeholders. This framework will be designed to broaden participation in the biotechnology workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Description: Biotech Partners (BP), in collaboration with Rockman et al Cooperative (REA) explored the local context of an overarching research question regarding partnerships with business and industry: In what roles and in what ways do bioscience educators and business and industry workforce members motivate students from diverse, underrepresented populations to become aware of, interested in, and prepared for careers in the STEM workforce?

BP’s program addresses inequities in STEM education by providing a student-centered, strengths-based model that integrates hands-on, paid industry internships with rigorous academic and career development training. This approach is reinforced by personalized mentorship and comprehensive wrap-around supports, which include counseling, academic tutoring, and emergency assistance with basic needs like transportation and housing. By aligning academic instruction with real-world life science industry practices, and offering individualized support tailored to students' unique strengths and challenges, BP empowers youth from historically underrepresented backgrounds to overcome systemic barriers to success in STEM career pathways.

Broader Impacts: Over the five-year grant period, BP facilitated 326 paid student internships, ensuring that all students who met the internship requirements and applied secured a job. The internship completion rate was over 95%, reflecting BP’s ability to engage and support students even in the face of significant challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic. The program achieved a 100% high school graduation rate among participating seniors, with most youth participants pursuing post-secondary education, and many beginning active early life science careers (Gurn et al, 2024b). 

BP adapted its programming in response to the pandemic, collaborating with longstanding and new partners to rapidly develop virtual and hybrid internships (Gurn et al, 2021). Students participated in intensive workshops co-led by The Carpentries, learning how to clean, organize, and analyze large datasets using Python and digital notebooks, then applying these data science skills in projects that analyzed data related to COVID-19, cancer research, and other topics. This pivot expanded BP’s focus beyond traditional lab-based internships, equipping students with skills in data science and remote collaboration, which are increasingly valuable in the STEM workforce. 

Biotech Partners’ internship program serves as a replicable model for creating sustainable partnerships between schools, communities, and industries that can effectively address youth barriers in STEM education (Gurn et al., 2024a). BP’s approach to integrating culturally responsive mentorship, academic preparation, and work-based industry experiences has demonstrated the potential to engage historically underrepresented students in meaningful life science career pathways.

Intellectual Merits: The project’s research highlighted the critical role that personalized mentorship plays in fostering a strong sense of belonging and identity within STEM fields. Through supportive mentoring relationships embedded in lab-based science education and industry internships, students develop both the professional skills and confidence needed to navigate the life science sector. Partnerships with industry help extend science learning beyond the classroom, creating professional connections and opportunities traditionally inaccessible to low-income youth of color. 

Throughout the internship experience, BP serves as a trusted guide for students into the unfamiliar world of bioscience careers, or as one science teacher noted, BP “prepares students for a trip to the other side of the moon” (Gurn et al., 2022). By offering paid internships alongside comprehensive wrap-around support, the program effectively removes socio-economic barriers that often prevent students from participating in unpaid work experiences. The opportunity to earn while learning makes the program more accessible and boosts students' motivation to meet the program's rigorous academic demands. This structure builds bridges between classroom learning and real-world bioscience applications, enhancing students’ educational experiences and professional readiness (Gurn et al, 2024b). 

The mentor-mentee relationship in BP internships fosters mutual growth. While students gain valuable technical skills and career insights, mentors are energized by the enthusiasm and curiosity interns bring to the workplace. These interactions often reinvigorate mentors, providing them with fresh perspectives and a renewed sense of purpose. Working with students from historically underrepresented groups also deepens mentors' cultural awareness, helping them better understand the challenges that young people face. This, in turn, contributes to creating more inclusive and supportive work environments. By guiding students through their STEM journeys, industry mentors help shape the next generation of STEM professionals, while refining their own supervisory and informal teaching practices (Gurn et al., 2024b).
